raw_text:
US consumer confidence up
 
 Consumers' confidence in the state of the US economy is at its highest for five months and they are optimistic about 2005, an influential survey says.
 
 The feel-good factor among US consumers rose in December for the first time since July according to new data. The Conference Board survey of 5,000 households pointed to renewed optimism about job creation and economic growth. US retailers have reported strong sales over the past 10 days after a slow start to the crucial festive season.
 
 According to figures also released on Tuesday, sales in shopping malls in the week to 25 December were 4.3% higher than in 2003 following a last minute rush. Wal-Mart, the largest US retailer, has said its December sales are expected to be better than previously forecast because of strong post-Christmas sales.
 
 It is expecting annual sales growth of between 1% and 3% for the month. Consumer confidence figures are considered a key economic indicator because consumer spending accounts for about two thirds of all economic activity in the United States. "The continuing economic expansion, combined with job growth, has consumers ending this year on a high note," said Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's consumer research centre. "And consumers' outlook suggests that the economy will continue to expand in the first half of next year." The overall US economy has performed strongly in recent months, prompting the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates five times since June.
llama3.2:1b: US consumer confidence up, optimism about 2005 high. Consumer feel-good factor rose in December for the first time since July. Retail sales strong after slow start to Christmas season. Wal-Mart expects annual sales growth of 1-3% for December.
llama3.2:3b: US consumer confidence reached its highest level in five months, with optimism about job creation and economic growth. Retail sales showed a 4.3% increase over 2003, driven by strong post-Christmas sales, and are expected to grow between 1% and 3% for December.
gemma2:2b: US consumer confidence is at its highest point in five months due to positive economic indicators like job growth and anticipated economic expansion. Retailers are experiencing strong sales, particularly during the holiday season. This positive sentiment indicates continued consumer spending, a significant driver of the US economy.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US consumer confidence is high and optimistic. A new survey indicates a 5-month peak for US consumers' outlook on the state of the economy and their satisfaction with job creation and economic growth. Retailers report strong sales after a difficult start, and consumer confidence figures are considered key indicators of economic health. The economy has been performing well recently, leading to Federal Reserve interest rate increases.
qwen2.5:1.5b: US consumer confidence surges as economic indicators show continued growth and optimism for 2005. Retail sales have improved following a slow start to the holiday season, with Wal-Mart expecting better-than-forecasted sales due to post-Christmas shopping. Consumer spending remains a key driver of US economic activity.
qwen2.5:3b: US consumer confidence up for first time since July, driven by renewed optimism about job creation and economic growth. Retail sales have picked up after a slow start, with December sales showing 4.3% higher year-on-year due to strong post-Christmas performance. Consumer confidence is considered a key indicator as it accounts for about two-thirds of US economic activity. The Conference Board director attributes the improvement to continued economic expansion and job growth, suggesting robust spending patterns into next year. Recently, the Federal Reserve has raised interest rates five times since June.
opencoder:1.5b: The output summary should focus on key points from the provided text that highlight US consumer confidence up, consumers' confidence in the state of the US economy is at its highest for five months, and optimism about 2005. The feel-good factor among US consumers rose in December as per new data according to new figures released on Tuesday. US retailers reported strong sales over past 10 days following a slow start to the festive season. According to figures also reported, sales in shopping malls increased from 25 December to 4.3% compared to 2003 for a period of next week. Wal-Mart reported strong sales that could be better than previously forecasted and the overall US economy performed well. Consumer confidence figures are considered a key economic indicator because they account for about two thirds of all economic activity in the United States, and the increasing growth and job progression will continue in the first half of next year.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and conveys the main ideas of the text without adding any additional information or explanations. It includes key phrases such as "consumers' confidence", "up", "optimistic", "2005", and "influential survey". The summary also captures the sentiment expressed in the text, which is positive and optimistic about the state of the US economy.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, so I need to summarize this text about U.S. consumer confidence and economic trends. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence says that consumer confidence is up at its highest for five months. That's a key point because it shows the economy is doing well. Then it mentions a survey indicating optimism about 2005, which suggests strong fundamentals.

Next, there's some data on consumer sentiment. They say the feel-good factor rose in December since July, so people are feeling better about their lives and the economy. That makes sense because last month was a slow start to the holiday season.

The Consumer Financial Services Association (CFSA) did this survey with 5,000 households. The data shows renewed optimism on job creation and growth, which is good news for businesses. The strong sales in retail stores over the past ten days after a slow start makes sense because holiday shopping usually brings people back to work.

Then it mentions that Wal-Mart's December sales are expected to be better than before because of post-Christmas rush. That probably means more consumers are spending during the holidays, so they're less stressed about the economic downturn at the end of the year.

The summary should include these points without getting into too much detail. I'll make sure to highlight the key themes: high confidence, strong sales data from retailers, positive retail sales growth, and how this affects consumer spending and economic performance with interest rates up due to the Fed's actions.

I need to keep it concise, just a sentence or two that captures all these elements.
</think>

US consumer confidence is up at its highest for five months, reflecting strong fundamentals. Consumer sentiment showed renewed optimism about 2005. Data revealed a rise in the feel-good factor in December since July, with increased spending over the holiday season. Retail sales saw a 4.3% increase compared to 2003 due to post-Christmas shopping. The economy is projected to grow between 1% and 3% annually for the month. Consumer confidence figures are key indicators as consumers spend about two-thirds of economic activity, with expectations suggesting strong future growth.
tinyllama:1.1b: Consumer confidence is at its highest for five months, with optimism about 2005's economic growth increasing by 1%, as per new data released by the Conferece Board survey of 5,000 households. Sales in shopping malls have experienced a strong Christmas season and are projected to be more than 4% higher compared to 2003, thanks to a last-minute rush among retailers. Wal-Mart, the largest US retailer, has announced it expects annual sales growth of between 1% and 3%, on strong holiday sales. Consumer confidence figures have been considered key economic indicators as consumer spending accounts for around two thirds of all economic activity in the United States. The continuing expansion of the economy is expected to continue into the first half of next year, according to market forecasts.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Consumers’ confidence in the state of the US economy is at its highest for five months and they are optimistic about 2005. This news comes from a revised survey by The Conference Board, which indicates that consumer spending has increased more than anticipated over the past month after an extended holiday slowdown. Sales in shopping malls were particularly strong during this period, with sales rising by as much as 4.3% compared to last year's levels. This improvement in retail sales is expected to result in better-than-expected annual growth for consumer confidence, according to Wal-Mart, the largest US retailer. The company has forecasted that its December sales will be stronger than previously estimated due to strong sales post Christmas. Additionally, consumers are expecting the economy to continue expanding throughout 2005, with their outlook reflecting this optimism. This report from The Conference Board signifies continued strength in US economic performance, as consumer confidence has begun to recover from a recent downturn.
phi:2.7b: In December, consumer confidence in the US economy increased for the first time in five months according to a survey by the Conference Board. This was due to optimism about job creation and economic growth. Sales at shopping malls also showed an improvement with 4.3% higher sales than in 2003. Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity in the United States, making consumer confidence figures a key economic indicator. The strong performance of the US economy has prompted the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates five times since June.
orca-mini:3b: US consumer confidence increased in December, according to a survey by the Conference Board. Consumers reported higher optimism about job creation and economic growth, indicating a strong economy and increased spending. Retail sales were 4.3% higher than in 2003 during the week of Christmas, with Wal-Mart reporting expected higher sales due to strong post-Christmas sales. The US economy has performed strongly in recent months, prompting the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates five times since June.
hermes3:3b: US consumer confidence highest in 5 months, up in December, optimism about job creation and economic growth.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: US consumer confidence is at its highest level in five months, with optimism surrounding job creation and economic growth in 2005. This optimistic sentiment was reflected in December sales for retailers, which reported strong profits following a slow start to the festive season. According to Conference Board survey data, US consumers' feel-good factor has risen, with an expected annual sales growth of 1%-3% for the month of December. As consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of all economic activity in the United States, these positive figures are considered a key economic indicator.
chatgpt-4o-latest: US consumer confidence reached a five-month high in December, driven by optimism about job creation and economic growth, according to a Conference Board survey. Retailers reported strong sales in the final days of the holiday season, with shopping mall sales up 4.3% from 2003. Wal-Mart expects better-than-forecast December sales due to strong post-Christmas shopping. Consumer confidence is a key economic indicator, as spending drives two-thirds of US economic activity. The economy has performed well, leading the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates five times since June.
stablelm2:1.6b: US consumer confidence is at its highest for five months due to optimism about job creation and economic growth, according to a survey by the Conference Board. Renewed optimism led to consumers reporting strong sales over the past few days, benefiting retailers. The Federal Reserve increased interest rates five times since June as the economy performed well. Consumer spending accounts for around two-thirds of all US economic activity.
granite3.1-dense:2b: US consumer confidence reaches its highest level in five months due to growing optimism about the economy for 2005. According to the Conference Board survey of 5,000 households, consumers show renewed enthusiasm for job creation and economic growth. Post-Christmas retail sales have surged, with a 4.3% increase compared to 2003. Major retailer Wal-Mart expects December sales to be better than forecast, projecting annual growth between 1% and 3%. Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of the US economy, remains robust, supported by a strong overall economic performance. The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates five times since June due to this economic expansion and job growth.
reference: Wal-Mart, the largest US retailer, has said its December sales are expected to be better than previously forecast because of strong post-Christmas sales."The continuing economic expansion, combined with job growth, has consumers ending this year on a high note," said Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's consumer research centre.The feel-good factor among US consumers rose in December for the first time since July according to new data.Consumers' confidence in the state of the US economy is at its highest for five months and they are optimistic about 2005, an influential survey says.US retailers have reported strong sales over the past 10 days after a slow start to the crucial festive season.
